description: The Capacity Bidding Program (CBP) is an aggregator-managed demand response program operated by Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E). The program is integrated with the California Independent System Operator (CAISO) wholesale market through Proxy Demand Resources (PDR). Aggregators receive monthly capacity payments for enrolled load reduction commitments and energy payments when events are called. PG&E triggers CBP events when it receives market awards from CAISO for PDR resources based on day-ahead market bids. The program operates during California's peak demand season from May through October.

service_territories: PG&E service territory in Northern and Central California
geography.notes: PG&E serves approximately 16 million customers across a 70,000 square-mile service area in Northern and Central California

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is available to all residential, commercial, industrial, and agricultural customers with qualifying interval meters. No minimum demand load requirement specified.

eligibility.aggregator_name: Third-party aggregators manage customer enrollment and operations
eligibility.meter_requirements: Each service account must have an interval meter capable of recording usage in 15-minute intervals that can be read remotely by PG&E. Approved interval meter and/or approved meter communications equipment must be installed and operating prior to participation.
ineligible_customers: Customers receiving electric power from WAPA or other 3rd parties that are not Direct Access or Community Choice Aggregation
eligibility.notes: CAISO PDR resources must meet a 100 kW minimum size requirement for wholesale market participation. CBP non-residential customers may also participate in PG&E's E-OBMC program or ELRP-B2 program. Battery storage systems are explicitly eligible for the program.

notification.notification_notes: PG&E will notify the affected aggregators by 5 p.m. on a day-ahead basis of a CBP event for the following calendar day. Aggregators then notify their enrolled customers.

seasonal_rates.source: Historical data from CPUC E-4020 shows May rates were lowest in the season

seasonal_rates.notes: Historical rate from CPUC E-4020. August typically has highest capacity payments. Current rates authorized through 2027 but specific values not publicly available.

capacity_rate.notes: Aggregators receive a monthly capacity payment based on the number of MWs nominated and the number of hours that those MWs will be reduced, even if a DRP event is not called. The capacity payment is a CPUC-approved price listed in the Capacity Bidding Program tariff (Schedule E-CBP). Current incentive rates are authorized by the CPUC through 2027. Historical data from CPUC E-4020 showed August 2006 rates at $21.57/kW-month for certain products, with capacity payments ranging from approximately $4 to $12 per kW per month depending on season and availability level (per web search results). Specific current rates require accessing the official E-CBP tariff document.

performance_rate.notes: Energy payment is what PG&E pays the aggregators for an event curtailment. If no CBP Events were called during the operation month, then the monthly energy payment is zero. Historical data from CPUC E-4020 indicates energy payments are based on city gate natural gas price with a trigger heat rate of 15,000 BTU/kWh. Paid for up to 150% of nominated demand reduction. The $6.00/kWh figure mentioned in previous research is actually a PENALTY rate for energy usage over the Firm Service Level (FSL) during a curtailment event, not a performance payment.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Participants are penalized at $6.00/kWh for energy usage over their Firm Service Level (FSL) during a curtailment event. Penalties vary based on load reduction shortfall, with larger penalties for larger shortfalls.

performance_thresholds.threshold: Less than 50% of nominated load delivered
Less than 95% of nominated load delivered

penalty_structure.notes: During months when one or more events are called, an aggregator receives its full capacity payment if at least 95% of the nominated load is provided. Aggregators receive a penalty, based on their kWh shortfall, if less than 95% of the nominated load is provided. Aggregators are penalized if they fail to deliver their committed load reductions, with penalties varying based on the shortfall.

payment_structure.payment_notes: Capacity payments fluctuate monthly, with the most valuable months being July-September. Average Capacity Bidding Program payment among current retail ADR participants mentioned as $4,400 per year (source unclear on participant size). Aggregators determine customer compensation within their portfolios. PG&E pays aggregators, who then pay participating customers.

seasons.notes: Program runs May 1 through October 31 but is promoted year-round for enrollment. Maximum 24 hours of events per month (from CPUC E-4020 historical data, current limits may vary).

call_windows.notes: May: 5:00 PM – 10:00 PM PT on non-holiday weekdays (from 2024 season data)
June through October: 4:00 PM – 9:00 PM PT on non-holiday weekdays (from 2024 season data)

event_parameters.notes: CBP-Elect option: Maximum of one event per day. Participant may choose more than 6 events per month. Maximum event duration: 4 hours. Interval meters record usage in 15-minute intervals. Historical data from CPUC E-4020 indicates weekdays from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. operating hours, though more recent sources indicate 4-9 PM or 5-10 PM windows depending on month.

event_triggers.trigger_description: PG&E may trigger a CBP Event for one or more Sub-LAP (Sub-Load Aggregation Point) when PG&E receives a market award from the CAISO for a PDR (Proxy Demand Resource) that's part of CBP as a result of the offer price specified by the aggregator for a nominated portfolio. Events are economically dispatched through CAISO's day-ahead energy market.
event_triggers.bidding_mechanism: Aggregators bid PDR resources into CAISO day-ahead market at specified offer prices
event_triggers.price_threshold: Net benefits test threshold (varies monthly, published by CAISO)
event_triggers.examples: Events are called when CAISO accepts aggregator bids in the day-ahead market during high-demand periods, typically during heat waves and peak summer demand
event_triggers.notes: CBP is integrated with CAISO's wholesale market through Proxy Demand Resources. All proxy demand resources must participate in the net benefits test that the ISO uses to set the monthly price threshold for cost effective demand response resource bids.

nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: Aggregators specify offer prices for their nominated PDR portfolios in the CAISO day-ahead market. For PDR-LSR (load shift resources), load curtailment can bid from the net benefits test threshold price up to the bid cap, and load consumption can bid from less than $0 to the bid floor.
nomination_bidding.caiso_registration: Sellers create customer locations using the CAISO's Demand Response Registration System (DRRS), which is needed for participating in the CAISO markets with PDR.
nomination_bidding.notes: Program is promoted year-round for enrollment. Aggregators manage the bidding process into CAISO markets and are responsible for portfolio nominations and bid price determination. Participants enroll through third-party aggregators rather than directly with PG&E.

special_attributes: Integrated with CAISO wholesale market through Proxy Demand Resources (PDR)
Economic dispatch based on market awards
Compatible with other PG&E DR programs (E-OBMC, ELRP-B2)

program_evolution.change_description: CPUC Resolution E-4020 (October 19, 2006) authorized PG&E, SCE, and SDG&E to implement the Capacity Bidding Program (CBP) to replace the California Power Authority Demand Reserves Partnership program.
Program continues with active participation. Current incentive rates authorized through 2027. Program operates May 1 - October 31 with day-ahead notification structure.

program_history.notes: Program has been operating continuously since 2006 authorization. Current incentive rates are authorized by the CPUC through 2027. PG&E has significant behind-the-meter battery deployment with BTM battery storage systems among PG&E customers totaling more than 1,100 megawatts through December 2024 — 35% of the nation's behind-the-meter storage capacity.

e_obmc_program.description: On-bill matched capability program compatible with CBP participation
e_obmc_program.penalty_description: $6 penalty for each kWh above power reduction commitment for customers who fail to meet load reduction requirements
e_obmc_program.notes: CBP non-residential customers may also participate in PG&E's E-OBMC program

elrp_b2_program.description: Emergency load reduction program compatible with CBP participation
elrp_b2_program.notes: CBP non-residential customers may also participate in ELRP-B2 program

sgip_program.description: Provides incentives for battery storage installations. All eligible non-residential customers must participate in one of these Demand Response programs: Capacity Bidding Program and Peak Day Pricing
sgip_program.notes: SGIP participants required to enroll in CBP or Peak Day Pricing for demand response participation

dram_program.description: Program where sellers bid aggregated demand response directly into the CAISO day-ahead energy market, with PG&E acquiring the capacity but having no claim on energy market revenues
dram_program.notes: DRAM is designed to be comparable and in alignment with the Capacity Bidding Program (CBP)

research_notes: Conducted comprehensive web research on PG&E Capacity Bidding Program on 2025-10-11. Program is well-established (operating since 2006 CPUC authorization) and integrated with CAISO wholesale markets through Proxy Demand Resource mechanism. Key finding: the $6.00/kWh figure mentioned in initial research is actually a PENALTY rate for exceeding Firm Service Level during curtailment, NOT a performance payment rate. Program has good documentation for structure and eligibility but specific current payment rates are contained in Schedule E-CBP tariff PDF which could not be fully accessed. Historical rate data from CPUC E-4020 shows August 2006 capacity payments at $21.57/kW-month for certain products. Web search results indicated capacity payments ranging from $4-$12/kW-month varying by season and availability level, with current rates authorized through 2027. Program is explicitly battery-storage friendly with significant BESS deployment in PG&E territory (1,100 MW BTM storage, 35% of national total). Aggregator-managed structure means many operational details determined at aggregator level. Day-ahead notification at 5 PM for next-day events. Program compatible with stacking (E-OBMC, ELRP-B2, SGIP). For complete current financial details, direct access to Schedule E-CBP tariff required. Overall data quality good for program structure and parameters but limited for specific current financial rates.

integration_metadata.api_notes: CAISO provides Demand Response Registration System (DRRS) for PDR registration. Aggregators likely have API access for dispatch notifications and telemetry, but documentation not publicly available. Program is AutoDR compatible indicating API/automated dispatch capability.
integration_metadata.verification_thoroughness: Comprehensive web research conducted including program webpage, CPUC regulatory documents, CAISO technical documentation, and multiple web searches. Primary limitation is inability to access current Schedule E-CBP tariff rates (PDF encoding issues). Successfully clarified $6/kWh as penalty not payment. Good understanding of program structure, eligibility, and integration mechanisms.
recommended_next_steps: Access Schedule E-CBP tariff document directly from PG&E (contact customer service or download via alternative method) for current capacity payment rates
Contact PG&E demand response team for detailed program parameters and current enrollment information
Research specific aggregators operating in PG&E territory (e.g., Enel, OhmConnect, others) for customer-facing program details
Access CAISO DRRS documentation for PDR registration and bidding procedures
Request historical event data from PG&E or aggregators
Investigate DRAM program as comparable alternative with similar CAISO integration
Review SGIP requirements for DR program participation to understand battery storage integration
Contact existing program participants for real-world experience data
integration_metadata.notes: Program is well-suited for battery optimization given: (1) Day-ahead notification allows for planning, (2) Defined call windows (4-10 PM peak hours), (3) CAISO market integration provides price signals, (4) Battery storage explicitly eligible, (5) Stacking allowed with other programs, (6) Aggregator structure provides operational flexibility. Key considerations: (1) Performance threshold is 95% minimum for full payment with penalties for shortfalls, (2) Events limited to peak hours but can occur frequently during summer, (3) Payment economics depend on specific capacity rates which require tariff access, (4) CAISO PDR requires 100 kW minimum which may limit small systems. Program appears compatible with behind-the-meter battery revenue stacking strategies. May-October season leaves Nov-April available for other revenue opportunities.
